‚òÖ  On making a conference lineup more diverse

(Or, why I didn‚Äôt submit to the PHP Unicorn conference)

I don‚Äôt usually blog about internal community struggles. They‚Äôre often important discussions to have, sure, but I usually don‚Äôt like to get involved. But this one is important to me, because I had an opinion on it before it was a problem. But I decided to keep silent at the time. In hindsight, maybe I shouldn‚Äôt have done.

So. The problem: (another) conference has a speaker lineup which is 10% female, 0% PoC. This problem is far too common; I‚Äôve called out conferences for this in the past. But the main difference in this case is Peter has held his hands up, admitted he could‚Äôve done better, and openly asked for (and importantly, listened to) advice on how to be better next year.

[By the way, Peter, if you‚Äôre reading this (and I hope you are): hats off for making this a learning experience for both you and other conference organisers. I have no beef with you or your conference, I want to watch but sadly I cannot get the day off work. I just wanted to share my experience to add to the pool of knowledge that‚Äôs out there.]

From what I can tell, the generally accepted reason why the conference doesn‚Äôt have a very diverse speakers lineup is because there wasn‚Äôt a very diverse choice of talk submissions. Which was caused by who the CfP was marketed to.

I saw the tweets advertising the CfP, but deliberately chose not to submit. I spent the last couple of days putting into words why that was. Here‚Äôs my attempt.

The tweet that I saw advertising the CfP was very close to this one:

Watch 8 of the top PHP experts (unicorns) in the world streaming live (or access the videos later) for just $50. https://t.co/fRWxIoGuZW

‚Äî PHP Unicorn Conf (@PHPUnicornConf) March 14, 2017

The three important words are ‚Äútop PHP experts‚Äù.

There were also two initial (I assume invited) speakers already announced: I guess this was to drive ticket sales. They are undoubtedly two well respected names in the community. And they‚Äôre both incredibly smart and accomplished people. Between them they have contributed to Core, written books, written very popular development tools, and keynoted at conferences.

So, that‚Äôs the level of this conference. Experts (or unicorns: legendary creatures known to be hard to capture). People who have contributed to php in a big way. Like, for example, writing books or contributing to Core.

Which is why I didn‚Äôt submit. I have never written a book (the most I‚Äôve done is written articles for other blogs), and I wouldn‚Äôt even know where to begin when it comes to contributing to the php language itself.

And is, probably, why many other people ‚Äì especially underrepresented people ‚Äì thought the same as me. That the CfP probably isn‚Äôt for them. The conference wants more intelligent people. More accomplished people. What am I doing even considering I deserve to share a stage with these giants of php?

Which is a lesson to all other conference organisers. I see the same faces on conference websites all the time. Some of these faces I saw at my very first conference I attended, almost 10 years ago. I literally learned my craft from these people.

If we want to bring in more speakers ‚Äì more diverse speakers ‚Äì we need to say that yes, you can submit to a CfP. It‚Äôs not for the elite, chosen, few. You don‚Äôt have to look, sound, or act like the other speakers you‚Äôve been watching and learning from for the last ten years.

We need to be say that even if you‚Äôve only been developing for a few years, you absolutely have something to say. Something which the most experienced developer can learn from. You bring something to the table, and we want to hear it. We promise.

We need to say that we don‚Äôt need unicorns on stage. We need YOU.

On Apple buying Workflow

I‚Äôm sure over the next few days, there will be lots of opinion pieces written and published by lots of different people over the news that Apple have purchased Workflow.

My opinion, however, isn‚Äôt that special. It‚Äôs little more than ‚Äúoh, that‚Äôs pretty cool. They wrote a great app, so good that Apple wanted in. They did pretty well there!‚Äù.

But there‚Äôs one part of the Techcrunch article announcing the deal which struck with me. It‚Äôs near the bottom, and it‚Äôs a couple of paragraphs about some words Apple said about the app:

Apple confirmed the deal, and has said the following about Workflow:

‚ÄúThe Workflow app was selected for an Apple Design Award in 2015 because of its outstanding use of iOS accessibility features, in particular an outstanding implementation for VoiceOver with clearly labeled items, thoughtful hints, and drag/drop announcements, making the app usable and quickly accessible to those who are blind or low-vision.‚Äù

The accessibility features of Workflow are super impressive, especially for an app that is a tool for building complicated macros. It would have been much easier to say hey, this is for heavy users maybe we don‚Äôt need to make sure it‚Äôs 100% accessible ‚Äî but they didn‚Äôt, and they won a bunch of awards (and an exit) for their trouble.

It‚Äôs all too easy to say that in an advanced app for pro users, with a lot of complicated features, accessibility isn‚Äôt at the top of the priority list. But Workflow has proven that it‚Äôs still an important thing for app developers to worry about.

And Apple, apparently, agrees.

‚òÖ  Is ISTQB worth it?

A common conversation among testers is certification, and whether it‚Äôs worth it. I only have experience with the ISTQB certification: I have both the Foundation and Advanced (Test Manager) certificates, so my opinions are on these.

I think that in certain circumstances, having an ISTQB pass to your name can be beneficial. Sure, lots of hiring managers might just ignore it, but in some cases you might want to consider the test anyway.

Your manager/company asks you to and pays for it

This is perhaps the most overlooked reason to attend an ISTQB course and take the test, whether or not you pass or fail. And I think it‚Äôs probably the most important reason. Heck, it‚Äôs the reason I have done it.

For me, the conversation started during my annual appraisal at work. I was given the objective to attend a course and to pass the examination. At the time, I didn‚Äôt have a clue what ISTQB even was: I was a newcomer to the testing world. But I accepted the objective, I attended the first course I could get onto, and during those three days I worked hard to make sure that I passed.

This made me look good to both my line manager and to the company as a whole. During my next annual appraisal I could say ‚ÄúI did this, because you asked me to it‚Äù, and it helped me prove to my line manager that I‚Äôm serious about improving my skills.

It also showed me that the company was serious about helping me increase my skills: they were happy to pay serious money for this to happen. To refuse to take up this offer would look bad. It shows dedication from both the employee and the employer.

It teaches trainees to a certain (minimal) standard

OK, so it may not be your company‚Äôs own processes and standards, but ISTQB is a good way to teach QA to those new to the field to at least some standard.

As long as the tester understands that the ISTQB foundation syllabus only touches the iceberg of QA ‚Äì and they are encouraged to continue learning ‚Äì I see no harm in using the ISTQB foundation course and examination as a ‚Äúkick start‚Äù to learning what you need to know to be a good tester.

Your enthusiasm during the course will be noticed

You never know who might be in the same room as you. It could be your next colleague, or even your next employer.

The training course before an ISTQB exam is a good way to show everybody how much you care about the art of QA. If you ask lots of questions, and generally try to get involved, you‚Äôll be remembered. And when it comes to your next job or your next promotion, getting noticed has never harmed anybody.

Of course, on the flip-side, if you‚Äôre sitting there looking bored and wondering what time lunch will be, that will be noticed, too.

It‚Äôs a standard vocabulary

OK, I know, you might not like this one, but it‚Äôs there. ISTQB is a standard. It might be a standard that you disagree with, but it gives us all a common vocabulary.

It helps imposter syndrome

This is why I took the Advanced (Test Manager) exam. Unfortunately, imposter syndrome is all too prevalent in our industry. Something objective to prove that you do indeed know what you‚Äôre doing can be a step towards controlling these doubts.

Conclusion

If you already have a career in QA, and have had one for at least a couple of years, then I don‚Äôt think it is worth the cost and time to take an ISTQB course and test. The value it gives you (a minimal standard of knowledge, and showing your dedication to your managers and peers) is something that you can show through your years of experience.

But for people who are new to testing ‚Äì less than a year ‚Äì I would absolutely recommend that if given the opportunity to sit the ISTQB, they should take it. They are still fresh and unproven, and there might be things that they just don‚Äôt yet know (as there may be concepts that just haven‚Äôt come up during day to day testing).

The courses are not cheap, granted. I only took a course because my employer paid for me. To be clear: I do not think that an individual should pay for an ISTQB training course. But the exam itself is affordable for individuals, and you can download the syllabus and sample exam papers for free from the ISTQB website for self-study. In fact, this is how I received my ISTQB Advanced (Test Manager) certificate.

‚òÖ  Developer and Tester

On my personal business card, it says ‚ÄúSoftware Developer/Tester‚Äù. I usually call myself a ‚ÄúSoftware Engineer‚Äù. I develop, and I test. And my CV has plenty of skills and experience in both.

But, can I really do both? Surely I can only do one or the other? Does it make me indecisive about my career choice and career path?

The short answers are yes, no, and no.

Let me give you the long answers

Can I really do both?

Why not? There is a lot of overlap in development and QA. Good project teams generally, in my opinion, are more successful when the developer and the tester are in constant communication.

It‚Äôs true, I prefer to test software than develop it, but that doesn‚Äôt mean I can‚Äôt develop software (or write automated tests) when the need arises. And it doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt have my own personal projects where I‚Äôm developing.

Surely I can only do one or the other?

We all know that in the tech industry, there‚Äôs specialists and generalists. Some argue that being one is better than the other. Me, I think that both types of people have very valuable skills that are useful in a project.

Very early in my career, I decided I was going to be a generalist. I was interested in a lot of things (I still am. My secret to being a good listener is I am genuinely interested in what the other person is talking about. Even if it‚Äôs about their trip to Morecambe with Aunt Sally. I just love to know things).

So I learnt as much as I could about development. I learnt PHP, and I learnt JavaScript. I learnt about Linux, because that‚Äôs what web servers ran on. There are people out there who know lots more about topics than I do, and honestly, it frustrates me. But I also know, I have enough baseline knowledge to be able to pick stuff up.

It‚Äôs the same now I‚Äôm testing. I might be a tester by day, but by night I‚Äôm learning Swift. I‚Äôll never be the expert in iOS development, and I‚Äôll probably have to Google some syntax, but I know enough to do a very good job.

I would prefer to also be able to test very well. I‚Äôm almost certain that there will be a ‚ÄúSelenium expert‚Äù who knows more than me, but does that really matter when I have enough broad knowledge to learn what I need to know?

Does it make me indecisive about my career choice and career path?

No. My day job is as a tester, with my career plan being to one day, be a test manager. And, if you ask me, the best managers are generalists. But that‚Äôs probably a blog post for another day‚Ä¶

Drop the crutchesüîó

I‚Äôve never really been that much of a fan of test cases. I like to call the method of going through a list of tests one by one ‚Äúcheckbox testing‚Äù. I don‚Äôt like how it encourages you down a specific path, and discourages you from doing what testers are good at: checking the quality of a product.

I always thought I was in the minority. I thought that my dislike of test cases made me, in some ways, a bad tester. I mean, I can write test cases. But almost every job description I see requires experience in doing so. I never understood this emphasis on something I didn‚Äôt think was a very good way of checking the quality of a product throughly.

So it was heartening to see the tweet thread, and this later blog post, by Michael Bolton, which includes this brilliant thought:

We also agreed that test cases often lead to goal displacement. Instead of a thorough investigation of the product, the goal morphs into ‚Äúfinish the test cases!‚Äù Managers are inclined to ask ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the testing going?‚Äù But they usually don‚Äôt mean that. Instead, they almost certainly mean ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the product doing?‚Äù But, it seems to me, testers often interpret ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the testing going?‚Äù as ‚ÄúAre you done those test cases?‚Äù, which ramps up the goal displacement.

I might have to bookmark this one, as a well thought out argument outlining the problems that come with test cases.

Why my emails are so short

It‚Äôs been brought up on a couple of occasions that my emails (heck, my online communication in general) are short. There‚Äôs a reason for this:1 I‚Äôve yet to decide whether it‚Äôs a good one or not.

I‚Äôve come to realise that in general, people don‚Äôt read entire emails. Given a two line email or a two page email, I‚Äôm more than likely to read (and follow up on) the former.

We all have busy lives, and we all get tens ‚Äì if not hundreds ‚Äì of emails every day. All asking for those two minutes of your time that nobody has, so we tend to be choosey on which emails we read, and respond to. And ‚Äì being the selfish type ‚Äì I want that email to be mine.

So, I write in short paragraphs, short sentences, and in short prose. In hope that you‚Äôre more likely to read what I have to say if I do. It probably means that I miss things out, and that things need further explaining. In which case, that‚Äôs best done over a followup email, phonecall, or face to face meeting (Speak to me face to face, and there‚Äôs a likelihood you won‚Äôt be able to shut me up).

If that sounds rude, or missing details, I‚Äôm sorry. Let me buy you a coffee as an apology?

(Of course, I‚Äôm not smart enough to come up with this myself. I learnt this from Oren Klaff, who sent out an email newsletter about this).
